metadata.title: How To Learn Data Science in 2020 | by Natassha Selvaraj | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: How To Learn Data Science in 2020
metadata.description: Ever since my previous post on landing a data science job, many readers have reached out to me on LinkedIn to ask for advice. Learning data science can seem extremely intimidating, and it is normal…

outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: 2020 Complete Python Bootcamp: From Zero to Hero in Pytho
Marian University — Applied Statistics for Social Science
MIT Open Courseware’s Introduction to Probability
post on creating data analysis projects

all_paragraphs: Ever since my previous post on landing a data science job, many readers have reached out to me on LinkedIn to ask for advice.
Most people asked me the same thing — “How can a complete beginner like me learn data science?”
Learning data science can seem extremely intimidating, and it is normal for you to feel overwhelmed when you start out.
There are plenty of MOOC’s out there that promise to teach you everything you need to know about the subject.
You read different blog posts every day that swear that this is the right path for you, and tell you how to become a data scientist in less than a month.
And somehow, none of these things have worked out for you.
Instead of following what everyone else claims works for them, create your own data science learning path.
In this article, I will go through everything you need to know to become a data scientist. I will also provide you with a list of resources you can learn from.
Using these resources, you can carve out a learning path that works best for you!
You will need to have some programming skills to learn data science. Pick one of the two languages — R or Python, and just start.
Learning how to code may seem like arduous task for a complete beginner, but it really isn’t that difficult.
When I was learning my first programming language, I asked my friend (who has had around ten years of programming experience) for coding advice.
He told me that there was one great skill all seasoned programmers had:
This is a habit you will need to develop to start learning to code. Start out with writing small pieces of code, and fixing bugs on your own.
Then start creating small projects of your own. You will learn a lot more along the way than just doing online courses.
Online courses are great for starting out, and they can set you on the right path, but they will not make you a programmer.
If you are a complete beginner — with no prior programming experience or statistical background, I suggest starting out with Python.
This is because Python is a highly versatile language, and its syntax is a lot easier to pick up on than other languages.
It will be a lot easier to learn your second and third programming language once you have a strong foundation in Python.
Step 1: Online Course — 2020 Complete Python Bootcamp: From Zero to Hero in Python
If you are an absolute beginner with no programming experience whatsoever, I would suggest taking this course.

It is an introductory course that will take you through the basics of Python programming. This course is taught in a Jupyter Notebook, which is great, since it is a coding environment you will be using in data science.
I haven’t taken this course, since I already had some programming experience before learning data science.

However, I did take a different course taught by the same instructor (Jose Portilla), and absolutely loved it. His teaching style is incredible, and he has a knack of breaking down complex concepts in a way that it is easy to understand.
After getting acquainted with the basics of the language, you need to practice.
HackerRank is a great website to do this, and it is completely free!
There are coding challenges in a variety of different languages, ranging from easy to hard.
The first few challenges are extremely easy and are a recap of all the concepts you already would’ve learnt — loops, arrays, conditional statements, etc.
The challenges get slightly harder after that and require some logic to solve. They are not that difficult, however, and are a great way to enhance your coding skills.

Every time I want to learn a new language, I spend around 4–5 hours a day solving HackerRank problems. This helps me get familiar with the language more quickly. After a few weeks, I am ready to start doing projects!
Now, you are ready to do projects!
This article provides some really great project ideas with varying levels of difficulty.
Start with some of the easiest ones, then work your way up.
After you finish all these, congratulations! You know how to code in Python.

At its core, data science is pretty much just statistics. Statistical concepts are used to derive insights from data and make decisions. Due to this, you will need a strong background in statistics to become a data scientist.
Step 1: Courses — Khan Academy
Khan Academy has a great statistics and probability course that you can take as an absolute beginner.
However, one thing I noticed when watching the lectures is that they only touch the surface of certain important topics. Due to this, I supplemented my learning with the resources in step 2.
Step 2: Marian University — Applied Statistics for Social Science
This website was a great resource to learn statistics. There are no video lectures to learn from, but every topic is explained in detail with great examples.
There are a large number of practice problems you can do, and it takes you through concepts from hypothesis testing to linear regression.
Learn the material and do all the practice problems, and you’ll have a better grasp on all these topics than if you learnt from any online course.
After learning basic statistical concepts, you should learn probability. Knowledge of probability is essential for a data scientist, because it shapes your decision making process.
MIT Open Courseware’s Introduction to Probability is a great place to start!
With knowledge of statistics and programming under your belt, you are now ready to learn data analysis!
Here, you will learn to derive insights from data using what you have learnt previously and extract useful information.
Step 1: Course — Foundations of Data Analysis
This is a great online course that teaches you how to apply statistics and programming to derive insights from data.
In fact, if you want to learn to analyze large amounts of data quickly and skip the previous two steps, this course is for you.
It is taught in R, and no former programming background is required to take the course.
Again, my advice would be to do projects.
Find a topic you are interested in, find a dataset, and start your analysis!
I have written an entire post on creating data analysis projects, and you can check that out for inspiration.
Finally, you can start to learn machine learning.
Machine learning is how you teach computers to learn and make decisions without explicitly programming them.
Data science is a broader term that takes you through the entire data processing methodology. Machine learning comes under data science, and is a large field in itself.
If you want to learn to do more with data, and come up with models to make predictions, then you should learn machine learning too.
There are just so many tools available for studying machine learning. However, most of the online courses only give you beginner to intermediate knowledge. They just aren’t deep enough.
Due to this, I will recommend some additional learning resources and books you can follow up these courses with.
Step 1: The Basics — Andrew Ng’s Machine Learning Course

Stanford’s legendary machine learning course is great for beginners to start out with. It teaches you how machine learning algorithms work without going too much into the math behind it, which makes it comprehensible for learners without a mathematical background.
One downside about this course, however, is that the practicals are taught in Matlab. If you want a Python alternative, I suggest doing this course instead.
First, learn linear algebra for data science. If you are a complete beginner, I suggest Khan Academy’s linear algebra lessons. MIT OpenCourseware also offers more in depth linear algebra classes.
Next, learn multivariable calculus. This is a link to the Khan Academy’s learning path, and this is a link to MIT OpenCourseware’s.
A few books that will supplement your learning process:
Step 4: Advanced Machine Learning Specialization — Coursera
This is a seven course machine learning specialization taught in Python. The pre-requisites include knowledge of machine learning algorithms, a mathematical background, and Python.
This course will bring you through everything from deep learning, to teaching you how to win Kaggle competitions by top Kagglers.
I hope this guide helps kickstart your data science journey.
Remember, you don’t have to learn these things in the same order I listed them.
I learnt data science using a bottom-up approach. Instead of learning the statistics and theory first, I started watching Kaggle tutorials and implementing machine learning algorithms in Python.
Then, I got curious about the underlying algorithm and how it worked, which is when I started to learn the math and theory behind it.
The resources I listed above were mostly the same ones I used during my learning process, but the order at which I approached it was different.
You can start your learning process any way you want, just do what works best for you.
Just be consistent, and you will get there. Good luck!
Your home for data science. A Medium publication sharing concepts, ideas and codes.
